articles.headline: Hefty Tax Break Spared in Health Care Bill
articles.snippet: Health Savings Accounts provide a nice tax break, but investors first have to hurdle the restrictions.
articles.abstract: Health Savings Accounts provide a nice tax break, but investors first have to hurdle the restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The health care bill that passed this week offers subsidies to people with low income so they can afford health insurance. To help pay for those subsidies, people with large incomes will have higher tax bills.

articles.headline: Kandahar, a Battlefield Even Before U.S. Offensive
articles.snippet: Bracing for an American offensive in the Afghan province, the Taliban are showing their power in an intensifying campaign of bombings and assassinations.
articles.abstract: Bracing for an American offensive in the Afghan province, the Taliban are showing their power in an intensifying campaign of bombings and assassinations.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — American forces have begun operations to push back Taliban insurgents in this most important southern province, the birthplace and spiritual home of the Taliban, and a full-scale offensive is expected in coming weeks.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Says Millions Got Unapproved Heart Pills
articles.snippet: About 80 percent of prescriptions for nitroglycerin are filled with unapproved, unvetted tablets, the agency said.
articles.abstract: About 80 percent of prescriptions for nitroglycerin are filled with unapproved, unvetted tablets, the agency said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Doctors in the United States wrote more than four million prescriptions last year for nitroglycerin tablets, heart drugs placed under the tongue to reduce the chest pain angina or to stop a heart attack.

articles.headline: Talent Agents a New Force in the Video Game Industry
articles.snippet: With the $46 billion worldwide market in upheaval, agents are increasingly useful for finding people to complete complex titles, structuring deals or obtaining financing.
articles.abstract: With the $46 billion worldwide market in upheaval, agents are increasingly useful for finding people to complete complex titles, structuring deals or obtaining financing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It happened to the motion picture industry in the 1930s and the music trade in the 1960s. Talent agents, initially brushed off as nothing more than opportunistic middle men, succeeded in making themselves vital parts of the machinery, helping the fast-growing but messy businesses mature.

articles.headline: For Years, Deaf Boys Tried to Tell of Priest’s Abuse
articles.snippet: The young victims of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy began alerting the authorities in the mid-1950s.
articles.abstract: The young victims of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy began alerting the authorities in the mid-1950s.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were deaf, but they were not silent. For decades, a group of men who were sexually abused as children by the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy at a school for the deaf in Wisconsin reported to every type of official they could think of that he was a danger, according to the victims and church documents.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and David Callender

articles.headline: Next Year in the White House: A Seder Tradition
articles.snippet: The Obama Passover Seder, one of the most intimate of White House traditions, began in the basement of a hotel.
articles.abstract: The Obama Passover Seder, one of the most intimate of White House traditions, began in the basement of a hotel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One evening in April 2008, three low-level staff members from the Obama presidential campaign — a baggage handler, a videographer and an advance man — gathered in the windowless basement of a Pennsylvania hotel for an improvised Passover Seder.

articles.headline: Agencies Suspect Iran Is Planning Atomic Sites
articles.snippet: Six months after the revelation of a secret nuclear enrichment site, inspectors and intelligence agencies suspect that Tehran is preparing to build more sites in defiance of United Nations demands.
articles.abstract: Six months after the revelation of a secret nuclear enrichment site, inspectors and intelligence agencies suspect that Tehran is preparing to build more sites in defiance of United Nations demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six months after the revelation of a secret nuclear enrichment site in Iran, international inspectors and Western intelligence agencies say they suspect that Tehran is preparing to build more sites in defiance of United Nations demands.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: With No Jobs, Plenty of Time for Tea Party
articles.snippet: The fact that many Tea Party supporters joined after losing their jobs raises questions of whether the movement can survive an improvement in the economy.
articles.abstract: The fact that many Tea Party supporters joined after losing their jobs raises questions of whether the movement can survive an improvement in the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — When Tom Grimes lost his job as a financial consultant 15 months ago, he called his congressman, a Democrat, for help getting government health care.

articles.headline: Death of a Loophole, and Swiss Banks Will Mourn
articles.snippet: Congress has taken aim at financial institutions that hide information about offshore accounts.
articles.abstract: Congress has taken aim at financial institutions that hide information about offshore accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH all the hoopla over the health care bill, hardly anybody noticed that a job creation bill that President Obama signed on March 18 makes it much harder for United States citizens to avoid taxes by hiding money in overseas bank accounts.

articles.headline: Day Traders 2.0: Wired, Angry and Loving It
articles.snippet: Day traders are still out there, betting that they can beat the odds and make money. And since the recession, many figure they can’t do any worse than Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Day traders are still out there, betting that they can beat the odds and make money. And since the recession, many figure they can’t do any worse than Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Encinitas, Calif.

articles.headline: Does This Bank Watchdog Have a Bite?
articles.snippet: Critics say John C. Dugan, the comptroller of the currency, often takes positions that align with the banking industry he regulates.
articles.abstract: Critics say John C. Dugan, the comptroller of the currency, often takes positions that align with the banking industry he regulates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Houston

articles.headline: Fleeing Rebels Kill Hundreds of Congolese
articles.snippet: The massacre and abductions were a setback to the effort to stamp out the remnants of the Lord’s Resistance Army.
articles.abstract: The massacre and abductions were a setback to the effort to stamp out the remnants of the Lord’s Resistance Army.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAPILI, Congo — Depleted by an American-backed offensive and seemingly desperate for new conscripts, the Lord’s Resistance Army, one of the most infamous armed groups in Africa, has killed hundreds of villagers in this remote corner of Congo and kidnapped hundreds more, marching them off in a vast human chain, witnesses say.

articles.headline: States Seeking Cash Hope to Expand Taxes to Services
articles.snippet: In the scramble to generate revenue, states are considering taxes on anything: dating services, bowling night, haircuts, even clowns.
articles.abstract: In the scramble to generate revenue, states are considering taxes on anything: dating services, bowling night, haircuts, even clowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the scramble to find something, anything, to generate more revenue, states are considering new taxes on virtually everything: garbage pickup, dating services, bowling night, haircuts, even clowns.

articles.headline: Obama Bypasses Senate Process, Filling 15 Posts
articles.snippet: The move suggests a newly emboldened president who is unafraid to provoke a confrontation with the minority party, even as he insists he still hopes to work in a bipartisan way.
articles.abstract: The move suggests a newly emboldened president who is unafraid to provoke a confrontation with the minority party, even as he insists he still hopes to work in a bipartisan way.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, making a muscular show of his executive authority just one day after Congress left for spring recess, said Saturday that he would bypass the Senate and install 15 appointees, including a union lawyer whose nomination to the National Labor Relations Board was blocked last month with the help of two Democrats.

articles.headline: In Afghan Trip, Obama Presses Karzai on Graft
articles.snippet: The visit reflected growing vexation with President Hamid Karzai as America’s military commitment to defeat the Taliban insurgency has deepened.
articles.abstract: The visit reflected growing vexation with President Hamid Karzai as America’s military commitment to defeat the Taliban insurgency has deepened.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Obama personally delivered pointed criticism to President Hamid Karzai in a face-to-face meeting on Sunday, flying here for an unannounced visit that reflected growing vexation with Mr. Karzai as America’s military commitment to defeat the Taliban insurgency has deepened.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Not Creating Content. Just Protecting It.
articles.snippet: When Google said it would leave mainland China, it struck a blow for free speech — and set a high standard for itself.
articles.abstract: When Google said it would leave mainland China, it struck a blow for free speech — and set a high standard for itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should we be surprised that the biggest fight over freedom of expression in years involves Google, a company that produces algorithms rather than articles?

articles.headline: Stocks Soar, but Many Analysts Ask Why
articles.snippet: Analysts see reason for caution in equities, with many economists forecasting tepid growth in the near term.
articles.abstract: Analysts see reason for caution in equities, with many economists forecasting tepid growth in the near term.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate remains locked in a range that recalls the economic doldrums of the early 1980s. Housing is stuck in a ditch, with foreclosures rising. And consumers are still reluctant to part with the little cash they do have.

articles.headline: Overqualified? Yes, but Happy to Have a Job
articles.snippet: As workers recalibrate their expectations amid the recession, companies are reaping unexpected rewards.
articles.abstract: As workers recalibrate their expectations amid the recession, companies are reaping unexpected rewards.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRANDVIEW, Mo. — Don Carroll, a former financial analyst with a master’s degree in business administration from a top university, was clearly overqualified for the job running the claims department for Cartwright International, a small, family-owned moving company here south of Kansas City.

articles.headline: North Koreans Use Cellphones to Bare Secrets
articles.snippet: Citizens feeding information about life in North Korea to the outside world represents a threat to the gulag state.
articles.abstract: Citizens feeding information about life in North Korea to the outside world represents a threat to the gulag state.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea, one of the world’s most impenetrable nations, is facing a new threat: networks of its own citizens feeding information about life there to South Korea and its Western allies.

articles.headline: Obama Team Is Divided on Anti-Terror Tactics
articles.snippet: Senior lawyers are divided over  the powers, including detention without trial, inherited from former President George W. Bush.
articles.abstract: Senior lawyers are divided over  the powers, including detention without trial, inherited from former President George W. Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior lawyers in the Obama administration are deeply divided over some of the counterterrorism powers they inherited from former President George W. Bush, according to interviews and a review of legal briefs.

articles.headline: Sony Pursues a Bold Success to Match Its Scale
articles.snippet: Once considered the innovator in the electronics business, the company has found itself playing catch-up for years, an embarrassment it hopes to end.
articles.abstract: Once considered the innovator in the electronics business, the company has found itself playing catch-up for years, an embarrassment it hopes to end.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAGOYA, Japan — The airy new Sony store in this central Japanese city has floor-to-ceiling windows, sleek white counters and friendly employees, called stylists, who offer advice and tailored counseling on Sony gadgets.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Face Fallout at Home From Health Vote
articles.snippet: Around the country, members of Congress found on-the-ground evidence of how the issue has divided the country.
articles.abstract: Around the country, members of Congress found on-the-ground evidence of how the issue has divided the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Alan Grayson, a Florida Democrat who supported President Obama’s health care bill, drew shouts of “amen” as he returned home on Friday. But his supporters did not publicize a speech he delivered Saturday morning, out of fear it would be disrupted by protesters.

articles.headline: Ford Agrees to Sell Volvo to a Fast-Rising Chinese Company
articles.snippet: The $1.8 billion purchase by the Zhejiang Geely Holding Group highlights China’s determination to capture market share around the globe.
articles.abstract: The $1.8 billion purchase by the Zhejiang Geely Holding Group highlights China’s determination to capture market share around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Ford Motor reached an agreement on Sunday to sell its Volvo subsidiary to a Chinese conglomerate, in the clearest confirmation yet of China’s global ambitions in the auto industry.

articles.headline: Analysts Ask if the iPad Can Live Up to Its Hype
articles.snippet: With high expectations for the tablet, Apple’s biggest challenge will be achieving the mass-market penetration and cultural impact of the iPod and iPhone.
articles.abstract: With high expectations for the tablet, Apple’s biggest challenge will be achieving the mass-market penetration and cultural impact of the iPod and iPhone.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the Apple iPad goes on sale on Saturday, most of the major questions surrounding the device will have been answered, save for one: can it live up to the hype?

articles.headline: Moscow Attack a Test for Putin and His Record Against Terror
articles.snippet: The bombings confronted Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin with a challenge to his record on terrorism, and raised the possibility that he would tighten his control over the government.
articles.abstract: The bombings confronted Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin with a challenge to his record on terrorism, and raised the possibility that he would tighten his control over the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The brazen suicide bombings in the center of Moscow confronted Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin with a grave challenge to his record of curbing terrorism, and raised the possibility that he would respond as he had in the past, by significantly tightening control over the government.

articles.headline: Militia Charged With Plotting to Murder Officers
articles.snippet: Members of a Christian militia were indicted on sedition and weapons charges in connection with an alleged plot to murder law enforcement officers.
articles.abstract: Members of a Christian militia were indicted on sedition and weapons charges in connection with an alleged plot to murder law enforcement officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mich. — David B. Stone Sr. and his wife, Tina, made no secret about the fact that they were part of a militia, neighbors say. The couple frequently let visitors in military fatigues erect tents in front of their trailer home at the intersection of rural dirt roads, and the sound of gunfire was routine.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Charlie Savage
